title: 109_s3490
content: The Act is titled the "Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge Study Act" and includes findings. The Cherry Valley area in northeastern Pennsylvania is home to over 80 special-concern animal and plant species, including 6 endangered or threatened species such as the bog turtle, dwarf wedge mussel, and bald eagle. Efforts are being made to reestablish favorable conditions for the Indiana bat. Cherry Valley provides habitat for over 80 special-concern animal and plant species, including 6 endangered or threatened species like the bog turtle, dwarf wedge mussel, bald eagle, and Indiana bat. Efforts are underway to support the Indiana bat population. Additionally, the area is home to 79 species of national or regional concern, including neotropical migratory birds and globally rare plants. Cherry Valley is home to neotropical migratory birds like the Cerulean Warbler and the Wood Thrush, waterfowl such as the American Black Duck, globally rare plants like the spreading globeflower, and anadromous fish species. The Cherry Valley watershed on the Kittatinny Ridge is an important migration route for birds of prey, including the bald eagle and golden eagle. The Kittatinny Ridge also hosts a variety of migratory raptor species during autumnal migration. The Kittatinny Ridge in Cherry Valley is a significant migration route for neotropical birds and raptors, including the bald eagle and golden eagle. The area also features the Appalachian Trail and rare wildlife habitats like calcareous wetlands. Ongoing studies show high water quality in Cherry Creek, and there are federal parcels of land nearby for potential inclusion in a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. Ongoing studies confirm high water quality in Cherry Creek. Two federally-owned parcels of land adjacent to the area may be included in a potential Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. Public meetings have shown strong local support for the refuge. Public meetings over several years have demonstrated strong local support for a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, with area landowners, business leaders, and elected officials showing enthusiasm. Local communities and conservation entities are actively conserving wildlife habitat and farmland, making them potential partners for the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. Local landowners, along with State agencies and the National Park Service, are potential partners for the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in establishing a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. Some landowners have already placed their land in conservation easements. Additionally, voter-approved open space funds in Monroe County and Stroud Township in Pennsylvania support land conservation efforts. Several local landowners have placed their land in conservation easements or other arrangements. Voter-approved open space funds in Monroe County and Stroud Township, Pennsylvania, have supported many conservation projects. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "map," "Secretary," and "Study Area." SEC. 4. STUDY OF REFUGE POTENTIAL AND FUTURE REFUGE LAND ACQUISITION. The Secretary will conduct a study to evaluate the Study Area for potential acquisition by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service for inclusion in a potential Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. Consultation with State and local officials, conservation organizations, landowners, and interested persons will be done to identify eligible land and determine boundaries for acquisition. The Secretary will conduct a study to evaluate the Study Area for potential acquisition for a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge. Consultation with various stakeholders will be done to identify eligible land and determine acquisition boundaries, assess conservation benefits, and suitability for inclusion in the National Wildlife Refuge System. The study will assess the conservation benefits of establishing a Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, including preserving diverse populations of fish, wildlife, and plants, protecting aquatic and wetland habitats, and providing opportunities for wildlife-dependent recreation and scientific research. The Secretary shall acquire not more than 30,000 acres for the Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, with a focus on protecting habitats, providing recreational opportunities, and fulfilling international obligations. Public participation and local input are important considerations for future land acquisition. The Secretary will acquire up to 30,000 acres for the Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, prioritizing habitat protection, recreation, and meeting international commitments. Public participation and local input are crucial for future land acquisition. A report on the study results must be submitted to the Senate and House committees within a year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will acquire land for the Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, with a focus on habitat protection and recreation. A report with a map and cost estimate for future land acquisition must be submitted to Senate and House committees. The Secretary is authorized to acquire land for the Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge, with a cost estimate and funds from non-Federal sources. $200,000 is authorized for this purpose.
